newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Euro-privatisations survive demise of fund.
newsitem.headline: Euro-privatisations survive demise of fund.

text.p: Fund managers say Euro-privatisations have a rosy future despite the demise of a big European privatisation fund but will not match the handsome returns enjoyed by British investors in the 1980s.
European fund managers facing a flood of privatisations before the turn of the century are not ready to turn their backs on these issues despite the death of the fund because of poor performance.
They said the future of such privatisations appeared rosier than two years ago but investors in such issues would not see the big profits seen in Britain in the 1980s.
"There is some great value out there and more to come," said Vicky Sleddon, manager of Mercury Asset Management's 719 million pound ($1.12 billion) European Privatisation Trust.
The Kleinwort European Privatisation Investment Trust Plc, which will not exist after November, fell victim to a poorly performing portfolio of shares, many of them French.
Among the investments it made in its two year-life were French car maker Renault, shares in which are now trading 35 percent under their November 1994 issue price.
Barry Verwee, European fund manager at Dutch fund manager AZL, said the problem with France's privatisation programme to date had been the sale of poor-quality companies.
"They weren't very well managed, there was too much government control and they weren't very efficient," he said.
Gary Dugan, European equity market strategist for J.P. Morgan Securities in London, said the concept of the European privatisation fund was "still a goer".
He said the newly-sold companies had suffered in the recent economic downturn in Europe and a high proportion of them were utilities, which typically do not offer above-average returns.
But most European share markets were expected to rise by 15 to 20 percent this year, he said. "In that environment, most of these privatisations should work," Dugan said.
Britain has blazed the privatisation trail for the world, raising $96.7 billion by selling state assets since 1983.
In a politically-motivated process which defined Margaret Thatcher's reign as prime minister, businesses were sold cheaply and made more attractive with post-privatisation sackings.
But Dugan believed such rich pickings unlikely in Europe, with governments retaining control of privatised companies.
European nations have raised $90 billion from privatisations with another $145 billion planned by 2000, including Deutsche Telekom in November and France Telecom next year.
The $10 billion sale of half of the German giant, Europe's biggest privatisation, is seen as an important test of demand with most fund managers at best cautious about its prospects.
"Given the huge amount of paper in that sector coming to the market, you cannot overprice it," said one manager.
Massimo Fortuzzi, director of investments at Italy's Finanza & Futuro Fondi, said the Euro-privatisation concept was still valid but these companies had to offer good growth prospects.
Hans-Joerg Frantzmann, a director of German private bank Schroeder Muenchmeyer Hengst, said: "There is no reason to damn the whole idea of Euro-privatisations and say it's all over."
He said the telecoms sector needed to be closely examined to see if it was still worthwhile, adding that he believed the Deutsche Telekom issue would be a success.
Scottish Widows fund manager Albert Morillo said he would not necessarily invest in privatisations.
"I don't think the concept is dead, they will carry on the privatisation programmes but it is not a focus of our attention," he said.
Dutch-based Robeco, Europe's largest independent fund manager, said it did not offer a Euro-privatisation fund because it saw no future in such a concept.
"It means putting all your eggs in one basket with the risk that there's nothing new you can buy (if privatisations dry up)," said portfolio manager Arjen Jongma. ($1=.6430 Pound)
